text.7_Chapter, 12_Verse: You who sit in the gardens, companions listen to your voice, let me hear [your voice].
text.6_Chapter, 10_Verse: I am my beloved’s and he longs for me.
text.2_Chapter, 8_Verse: A canopy has King Shlomo made of the wood of Levanon.
text.6_Chapter, 9_Verse: And let your speech be like good wine; it flows for my beloved in sincerity, causing the lips of sleepers to murmur.
text.2_Chapter, 9_Verse: Its pillars he made of silver, its covering of gold, its curtain of purple wool; its interior bedecked with love from the daughters of Yerusholayim.
text.7_Chapter, 10_Verse: Shlomo had a vineyard in the Plain of Hamon, he gave over the vineyard to caretakers; each of them brought for its fruit a thousand pieces of silver.
text.0_Chapter, 10_Verse: Circlets of gold we will make for you with spangles of silver.
text.4_Chapter, 7_Verse: I bind you under oath, daughters of Yerusholayim; when you find my beloved, what will you tell him? that I am lovesick [for him.]
text.7_Chapter, 3_Verse: I bind you under oath daughters of Yerusholayim why should you cause hatred or disturb [this] love while it still pleases?
text.0_Chapter, 9_Verse: Your cheeks are comely with rows of gems your neck with [pearl] necklaces.
text.6_Chapter, 1_Verse: How fair were your feet in sandals, O daughter of nobles; the roundness of your flanks, are like jewels, the work of a craftsman.
text.3_Chapter, 9_Verse: How beautiful is your love my sister, O bride; how superior is your love to wine, and the fragrance of your oils to all perfumes.
text.5_Chapter, 5_Verse: Your teeth are like a counted flock which have come up from the washing; all of which are perfect and none are blemished among them.
text.0_Chapter, 2_Verse: Like the fragrance of good oils, your name is like flowing oil; therefore young maidens love you.
text.0_Chapter, 6_Verse: Tell me, you whom my soul loves, where do you graze your flock where do you rest your flock at noon; for why should I flit about around the flocks of your companions?
text.5_Chapter, 10_Verse: I went down to the garden of nuts, to see the moist plants of the valley; to see whether the vine had blossomed, if the pomegranates had sprouted.
text.5_Chapter, 6_Verse: Like a slice of pomegranate are your cheeks from within your kerchief.
text.0_Chapter, 3_Verse: Draw me, we will run after you; the king has brought me into his chambers, we will be glad and rejoice in you, we recall your love more than wine, they loved you sincerely.
text.7_Chapter, 2_Verse: His left hand is under my head and his right hand embraces me.
text.5_Chapter, 8_Verse: But she is unique, my dove, my perfect one, she is unique to her mother, she is pure to her who begot her; daughters saw her and acclaimed her, queens and concubines, and they praised her.
text.1_Chapter, 13_Verse: My dove, in the clefts of the rock, in the concealment of the cliff, show me your countenance, let me hear your voice; for your voice is sweet and your countenance is comely.
text.3_Chapter, 0_Verse: Behold you are beautiful, my beloved, behold you are beautiful, your eyes are like doves from within your kerchief; your hair is like a flock of goats descending from Mount Gilad.
text.1_Chapter, 5_Verse: His left hand was under my head and his right would embrace me.
text.2_Chapter, 6_Verse: Behold the bed of Shlomo, sixty mighty men are around it; of the mighty men of Yisroel.
text.0_Chapter, 5_Verse: Do not look upon me [with contempt] that I am so black, for the sun has tanned me; my mother’s sons were incensed against me, they made me keeper of the vineyards, [but] my own vineyard I did not watch.
text.1_Chapter, 1_Verse: As a rose among the thorns, so is my beloved among the daughters.
text.0_Chapter, 1_Verse: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth, for your love is dearer than wine.
text.3_Chapter, 11_Verse: A locked garden is my sister, O bride; a locked up spring, a sealed fountain.
text.6_Chapter, 7_Verse: Such is your stature, likened to a [stately] palm tree; and your breasts are like clusters.
text.3_Chapter, 3_Verse: Your neck is like the Tower of Dovid, built as a model of beauty; a thousand shields are hung upon it, all the quivers of the mighty.
text.1_Chapter, 10_Verse: For behold, the winter is past, the rain is over, and gone.
text.7_Chapter, 6_Verse: Many waters cannot quench the love, and rivers cannot drown it; if a man would give all the wealth of his house for love they would surely scorn him.
text.2_Chapter, 10_Verse: Go forth and gaze, daughters of Tzion, upon King Shlomo; upon the crown with which his mother adorned him on the day of his wedding, and on the day his heart rejoiced.
text.5_Chapter, 11_Verse: I did not know, my soul set me like chariots of a noble people.
text.0_Chapter, 7_Verse: If you do not know [you who are the] fairest of women; go forth in the footsteps of the sheep and pasture your kids near the dwellings of the shepherds.
text.1_Chapter, 2_Verse: As an apple tree among the trees of the forest, so is my beloved among the sons; in its shade I delighted and sat, and its fruit was sweet to my palate.
text.3_Chapter, 13_Verse: Spikenard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with all the trees of frankincense; myrrh and aloes with all the major spices.
text.6_Chapter, 5_Verse: That which is upon your head is like Mount Carmel, and the braid of your head is like [royal] purple wool; your King is bound in its tresses.
text.7_Chapter, 4_Verse: Who is she that rises from the wilderness, clinging to her beloved? beneath the apple tree I aroused you, there your mother had birth pains there she who bore you suffered.
text.5_Chapter, 4_Verse: Turn your eyes away from me, for they made me haughty; your hair is like a flock of goats descending from Mount Gilad.
text.1_Chapter, 4_Verse: Sustain me with dainty cakes refresh my bed with [the scent of] apples; for I am lovesick.
text.7_Chapter, 1_Verse: I would lead you, I would bring you to my mother’s house that you should teach me; I would give you spiced wine to drink, of the nectar of my pomegranate.
text.3_Chapter, 7_Verse: With me [will you come] from Levanon O bride, with me from Levanon will you come; you will look from the peak of Amanah, from the peaks of Snir of Chermon, from the lions’ dens, from the mountains of leopards.
text.1_Chapter, 14_Verse: Seize for us the foxes, little foxes that destroy vineyards [for] our vineyards are with tender grapes.”
text.4_Chapter, 12_Verse: His cheeks are like a bed of spice, like towers of perfumes; his lips are like roses, dripping [with] flowing myrrh.
text.2_Chapter, 1_Verse: I will rise now and roam through the city, in the market places and in the streets, I will seek him whom my soul loves; I sought him but did not find him.
text.1_Chapter, 15_Verse: My beloved is mine, and I am his, who pastures among the roses.
text.3_Chapter, 6_Verse: You are completely beautiful, my beloved, and you are without blemish.
text.0_Chapter, 4_Verse: I am black, but comely, daughters of Jerusalem; like the tents of Kedar, like the curtains of Shlomo.
text.2_Chapter, 0_Verse: On my bed at night, I sought him whom my soul loves; I sought him but did not find him.
text.6_Chapter, 13_Verse: The baskets emit fragrance, and at our door are all luscious fruits, both new and old; my beloved, I have kept them for you.
text.6_Chapter, 6_Verse: How beautiful and pleasant are you; a love with delights.
text.3_Chapter, 10_Verse: Your lips drip flowing honey, O bride; honey and milk are under your tongue, and the fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Levanon.
text.2_Chapter, 5_Verse: Who is this ascending from the wilderness, with palm-like pillars of smoke; in a cloud of myrrh and frankincense, of all the powders of the perfume seller?
text.0_Chapter, 8_Verse: To steeds in the chariots of Pharaoh I have likened you, my beloved.
text.7_Chapter, 0_Verse: If only you were a brother to me, who had nursed at my mother’s bosom; when I would find you outside I would kiss you, and no one would scorn me.
text.4_Chapter, 10_Verse: His head is [like] finest gold, his locks hang, they are raven-black.
text.7_Chapter, 11_Verse: My vineyard is before me; the thousand are yours, Shlomo, and two hundred are for those who guard its fruit.
text.2_Chapter, 3_Verse: Scarcely had I departed from them, when I found him whom my soul loves; I grasped him and would not let him go until I brought him to my mother’s house and to the chamber of her who conceived me.
text.4_Chapter, 8_Verse: With what does your beloved excel another beloved, most beautiful among women? With what does your beloved excel another beloved, that you bind us under oath?
text.2_Chapter, 7_Verse: All of them holding swords, skilled in battle; each with his sword at his side for fear of the nights.
text.1_Chapter, 0_Verse: I am a rose of Sharon a rose of the valleys.
text.7_Chapter, 13_Verse: Flee my beloved and be like a gazelle or a young hart upon the mountains of spices.
text.1_Chapter, 12_Verse: The fig tree has produced its green figs, and the grapevines tender grapes give out their fragrance; arise my beloved, my fair one, and go forth.
text.4_Chapter, 2_Verse: I have removed my robe, how can I put it on? I have washed my feet, how can I soil them?
text.0_Chapter, 15_Verse: You are handsome, my beloved, most handsome; indeed our bed is fresh.
text.4_Chapter, 6_Verse: The watchmen found me, those who go about the city, they struck me, they wounded me; they stripped my ornament from me, [even] the guards of the walls.
text.0_Chapter, 11_Verse: While the king was at his table, my spikenard gave out its fragrance.
text.4_Chapter, 13_Verse: His hands are like rolls of gold studded with precious gems; his innards sparkle like ivory, overlaid with sapphires.
text.6_Chapter, 4_Verse: Your neck is like an ivory tower; your eyes are like pools in Cheshbon, at the gate of the populated city, your face is like a tower of Levanon looking out as far as Damascus.
text.3_Chapter, 12_Verse: Your arid fields are a pomegranate orchard with luscious fruits; henna with spikenard.
text.3_Chapter, 1_Verse: Your teeth are like a counted flock which have come up from the washing; all of which are perfect and none are blemished among them.
text.4_Chapter, 9_Verse: My beloved is pure white and ruddy, surrounded by myriads.
text.4_Chapter, 15_Verse: [The words of] his palate are sweet, and he is all delight; this is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Yerusholayim.
text.5_Chapter, 1_Verse: My beloved has gone down to his garden, to the beds of spices; to graze in the gardens and to gather roses.
text.1_Chapter, 8_Verse: My beloved resembles a gazelle or a young hart; behold, he stands behind our wall, observing through the windows peering through the lattices.
text.0_Chapter, 16_Verse: The beams of our houses are cedars, our panels are cypresses.
text.4_Chapter, 1_Verse: I slept but my heart was awake; a sound! My beloved knocks, open for me, my sister, my love, my dove, my perfection, for my head is drenched [as though] with dew, my sidelocks drip with the rains of the night.
text.0_Chapter, 12_Verse: A bundle of myrrh is my beloved to me, between my breasts he shall lie.
text.4_Chapter, 5_Verse: I opened for my beloved, but my beloved had vanished and gone; my soul departed as he spoke, I sought him but could not find him, I called him but he would not answer.
text.2_Chapter, 2_Verse: The watchmen found me those who circle about the city; him whom my soul loves, have you seen him?
text.6_Chapter, 3_Verse: Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle.
text.1_Chapter, 11_Verse: The blossoms have appeared on the land, the time of singing has come; and the voice of the turtledove is heard in our land.
text.3_Chapter, 2_Verse: Like a scarlet thread are your lips, and your speech is comely; like a slice of pomegranate are your cheeks from within your kerchief.
text.5_Chapter, 7_Verse: There are sixty queens and eighty concubines, and young maidens without number.
text.5_Chapter, 2_Verse: I am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine, who grazes among the roses.
text.0_Chapter, 14_Verse: Behold you are beautiful, my beloved, behold you are beautiful; your eyes are like doves.
text.4_Chapter, 3_Verse: My beloved sent forth his hand from the portal, and my innards longed for him.
text.7_Chapter, 5_Verse: Set me as a seal upon your heart as a seal upon your arm, for love is as strong as death, jealousy is as harsh as the grave; its flashes are flashes of fire from the flame of God.
text.6_Chapter, 12_Verse: Let us rise early for the vineyards, let us see if the vine has blossomed, if the tender grapes have appeared, if the pomegranates are in bloom; there I will give my love to you.
text.4_Chapter, 14_Verse: His legs are like pillars of marble set in sockets of fine gold; his appearance is like Levanon chosen like the cedars.
text.6_Chapter, 11_Verse: Come, my beloved, let us go out to the field, let us lodge in the villages.
text.6_Chapter, 8_Verse: I said, I will ascend the palm tree, I will grasp its branches; and now, let your breasts remain like clusters of the vine, and the fragrance of your face like apples.
text.5_Chapter, 0_Verse: Where has your beloved gone O fairest among women? Where has your beloved turned that we may seek him with you?
text.3_Chapter, 5_Verse: Until the sun spreads and the shadows flee; I will go to Mount Moriyah and to the hill of frankincense.
text.1_Chapter, 16_Verse: Until the sun spreads and the shadows flee; you turned away, my beloved, and became like a gazelle or a young hart on distant mountains.
text.6_Chapter, 2_Verse: Your navel is like a round bowl, which lacks not for mixed wines; your stomach is like a heap of wheat, hedged about with roses.
text.3_Chapter, 14_Verse: You are a garden spring, a well of living waters; and flowing streams from Levanon.
text.4_Chapter, 0_Verse: I have come to my garden, my sister, O bride, I have gathered my myrrh with my spice, I have eaten my sugar cane with my honey, I have drunk my wine with my milk; eat [my] friends, drink and become intoxicated, [my] beloved ones.
text.1_Chapter, 3_Verse: He brought me to the banqueting-house, and his banner is raised over me in love.
text.1_Chapter, 6_Verse: I bind you under oath, daughters of Yerusholayim by the gazelles and the does of the field; that you do not cause hatred nor disturb this love while it still pleases.
text.6_Chapter, 0_Verse: Turn back, turn back [you] perfect one, turn back, turn back, that we may observe you; what can you see [offer] the perfect one that equals the encirclement of the camps?
text.3_Chapter, 4_Verse: Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle who pasture among the roses.
text.5_Chapter, 3_Verse: You are beautiful, my beloved, as Tirtzah, comely as Yerusholayim, awesome as the hosts [of angels].
text.4_Chapter, 4_Verse: I arose to open for my beloved; and my hands dripped myrrh, and my fingers flowed with myrrh from the handles of the lock.
text.0_Chapter, 13_Verse: A cluster of henna is my beloved to me in the vineyards of En-gedi.
text.3_Chapter, 8_Verse: You captured my heart, my sister, O bride; you captured my heart with but one of your eyes, with one necklace of your necklaces.
text.7_Chapter, 9_Verse: I am a wall and my bosom is like towers; therefore I am in his eyes as one who found peace.
text.7_Chapter, 7_Verse: We have a little sister but she has no breasts; what shall we do for our sister on the day she is spoken for?
text.4_Chapter, 11_Verse: His eyes are like doves upon brooks of water; bathed in milk, well set in their fullness.
text.2_Chapter, 4_Verse: I bind you under oath, daughters of Yerusholayim by the gazelles and the does of the field; that you do not cause hatred nor disturb this love while it still pleases.
text.5_Chapter, 9_Verse: Who is this that gazes down like the [breaking] dawn, beautiful as the moon, bright as the sun, awesome as the hosts [of angels]?
text.1_Chapter, 9_Verse: My beloved spoke and said to me, “Rise up, my beloved, my fair one, and go forth.
text.1_Chapter, 7_Verse: The voice of my beloved! Behold he comes; leaping over the mountains, skipping over the hills.
text.7_Chapter, 8_Verse: If she be a wall we will build upon her a fortress of silver, if she be a door, we will enclose her with panels of cedar.
text.3_Chapter, 15_Verse: Awake, wind from the north and come, wind from the south, blow upon my garden so that its fragrance may flow; let my beloved come to his garden, and eat its luscious fruit.
text.0_Chapter, 0_Verse: The song of songs which is Shlomo’s.
